comments.commentBody: RUBY IS CORRECT.  Anyone who has escaped "Milk does a body good" BS (Bad Science) from childhood and the Dairy lobby realizes that Baby Cow Bovine Growth Fluid is SPECIFICALLY for baby cows - not humans. WHEW!

Sorry Susan. You obviously know next to nothing about appropriate sources of calcium. Non-species-specific milk is not a good idea for humans. Susan's post from Eastern WA is one of the silliest yet. When I read these kind of unscientific simplistic popular myths I fear for our country. Where to start? Take a deep breath and read the China Study for starters, before you go on. One good book or internet resource leads to another. There are zillions of related hits on the internet relating to T. Colin Campbell et al.

In Susan's defense, the NYT article was even sillier than her post.

Can anybody explain why the demonization of pasteurization?  We cook meat--why is milk different?  That said, my 30-month old son still nurses and doesn't seem to like cow's milk, but does enjoy cheese (so I'm not particularly pro-milk. I like it in my coffee.)

IT MADE MY DAY TO SEE SO MANY PEOPLE TELLING THE TRUTH ABOUT MILK..

NYT FOLKS WORKING ON THE ARTICLE SHOULD STUDY NYT ARCHIVES.
For starters search "T. Colin Campbell" and "China Study" cited in the NYT.

Cheers.

Well written. Makes me remember my own grandmother and the Wednesday meals. The food was old school - so simple and tasty.

Mostly I remember when we'd leave - She always stood on the porch and waived goodbye, saying a prayer silently. Those prayers I always felt were just as nourishing as her meals.

Budgets are not depleted in Scandinavia because of the high personal tax rates - Denmark recently cut their top tax rate from 62% to 55%.  The top rate kicks in at a surprisingly low income threshold.  We could have similarly excellent care for our elders if we were as willing to pay for it as they are.  But agree with you that they save by not having troops around the world AND paying very high taxes.  Why do we STILL have over 30,000 troops in Europe, even after cutting 10,000?

Dr. rosy, you are exactly right.  My brother and I (in our early 60s) are coping with an 85-year-old mom who has had falls, long-lasting spells of vertigo, infections, and other problems.  She's got plenty of money, has been diagnosed with early dementia, and is completely in denial about her situation.  She can't follow through on things and won't/can't take directions.  Thank god my brother has power of attorney for financial matters.  Mom chooses to live 2500/5000 miles away from us, while professing to love and respect our concerns and suggestions.  She won't do anything that "old people" do, like having a stair-chair installed at home, hire housekeeping or cooking help, or wear a Life Alert button.  After her latest stint at assisted care, she'll probably return home in a month or so, left to her own devices.  And oh by the way, she has an incompetent doctor who  she loves--and will let her do what she wants.  Brother and I will seek court guardianship (a long, expensive, drastic process) if mom survives the next fall or crisis.

So what happens if you fall in love with someone and the relationship is going swimmingly, and THEN in preparation for a possible merge you find out they're financially irresponsible, in a hole, or will likely bankrupt you?

... and once everyone gets the legal right to marry, we can all just choose not to, keep our finances separate, and get along as consenting adults who have to actually communicate and learn, rather than "shop" for a "mate."

Thank you for giving voice to my plans - as one who has no siblings or children - this is what I plan to do with substitutes for the pentobarbital.

As Greta Garbo said, "I'd rather be alone".

But 50 years ago, that grandmother might have been 70-75, and the daughter(s) 45-50. I think there's a big difference in ability to provide physical care when the aged person is 90 and the daughters (always daughters) are 60 and up.
Death from an overdose is a much messier and more agonizing affair than just going into a peaceful sleep, unfortunately.

In my experience, hospital social workers are singularly focused on moving people out of hospital beds and aren't little or no help at all in providing elder care advice. When my father needed a week of rehab after receiving a pacemaker, the social workers told me he had to go to a nursing home. I fought them and ended up calling a hospital with an in-patient cardiac rehab unit on the advice of a friend. A nurse in the rehab unit said they'd take him and I then marched back to the social workers and told them to make it happen.

The best resource I've found is old fashioned word of mouth - friends who have successfully navigated some aspect of this for themselves or their parents.

Here's a important lesson I learned in the case of my father: when the social worker came to see him after his surgery, she saw an 80-something man and immediately said that he looked like a case for "sub-acute" rehab. That made sense to me, since he was certainly not in bad shape -- but I made the error of apply common sense to a term of art used in the healthcare system: in the parlance of rehab care, "acute" rehab is where the patient gets several hours of physical and/or occupational therapy a day, while in "sub-acute" rehab (which appear to be provided only in nursing homes) the patient gets *at most* an hour a day. Since then, I've learned that otherwise healthy Medicare patients are routinely sent to "sub-acute" rehab after joint replacement, which makes no sense at all.
You can't rely on your kids. LTC insurance is your friend.

One can watch old TV shows from the mid 50's and psychiatrists then were being paid $50 per hour.  This was back when a surgeons made about the same for an operation.  Psychiatrists aren't being reimbursed much more now while surgeons can easily make $5000 or more for an operation.  Is there any question as to why virtually no graduates of U.S. medical schools enter psychiatry anymore.
How many seniors can afford your services?  Almost $200,000 per year is more than many have in their entire next egg.
Surely you don't mean suicide as the main way out?  Is this what you want or is it your parents' desire?  With decent, affordable care, would they still want it?

My mother and stepfather were in Piper Shores in Scarbourough, ME.  I was very impressed with the place.  My husband and I looked for a similar place in CA, but they were much more expensive.  When he had his last illness, we had round-the-clock caregivers because he didn't want to be in a nursing care facility.  It was a lot more expensive than $150 a day.

They will have at least $250,000 more for each child they did not have and will be able to pay for the care they need.

There is always a trade-off.

My grandmother had the same attitude and it is very selfish. She lived in an isolated area, but thought that one of her granddaughters should quit their job and move in with her.

We tried to get her to move closer to one of us, to no avail. She died at home with only a live in aide for company, but that was her choice.

Perhaps you should not have promised that, as if your own health fails, what then?

Our children are not our servants and should not be treated as if they are.
Illegal immigrants, obviously.
The children who do so appear to be brainwashed into believing they are slaves to whatever whim their elders desire. Very strange.
bbshort: It seems that what you are doing is beyond the pale. Your sisters should be in assisted living, which is where they will be, once you make yourself sick being their maid and nurse.

comments.commentTitle: I wonder if critics see the same movie as the public see
comments.commentBody: After reading this review, I was apprehensive about going to see this movie. However this review could not be more wrong. The hobbit is a wonderful movie and I cannot wait for the release of the second part next year. You got to wonder if critics see the same movie as the public see or  maybe, they make up their  mind before actually seeing it.
